qas.question: What remained an important issue in Scottish national identity for many years?

answers.text: lack of a Parliament of Scotland
the lack of a Parliament of Scotland
the lack of a Parliament of Scotland

qas.question: How many hundred of years was Scotland directly governed by the parliament of Great Britain?
Why were the initial suggestions for a devolved parliament before 1914 shelved?

answers.text: the outbreak of the First World War

qas.question: When was there a sharp rise in nationalism in Scotland?
What did Kllbrandon's report in 1973 recommend establishing?
What was not considered an important element in Scottish national identity?
The Second World War caused what to be shelved?

plausible_answers.text: demands for some form of home rule or complete independence

qas.question: A decline in Scottish nationalism during the 1960s fueled what?

plausible_answers.text: examine ways of enabling more self-government for Scotland

qas.question: The only objective of the Kilbrandon Commission was what?
Harold Wilson published a report in what year?

context: For the next <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>three hundred<a1_0/> years<a1_2/><a1_1/>, Scotland was directly governed by the Parliament of Great Britain and the subsequent Parliament of the United Kingdom, both seated at Westminster, and <a0_1><a0_2>the <a0_0><b5_0>lack of a Parliament<b5_0/> of Scotland<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> remained an important element in Scottish national identity. <b6_0>Suggestions for a 'devolved' Parliament<b6_0/> were made before 1914, but were shelved due to <a2_2>the outbreak of the <a2_0><a2_1>First World War<a2_2/><a2_1/>.<a2_0/> A sharp rise in nationalism in Scotland during <a3_0>the <a3_1><a3_2>late 1960s<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> fuelled <b7_0>demands for some form of home rule or complete independence<b7_0/>, and in 1969 prompted the incumbent Labour government of Harold Wilson to set up the Kilbrandon Commission to consider the British constitution. One of the principal objectives of the commission was to <b8_0>examine ways of enabling more self-government for Scotland<b8_0/>, within the unitary state of the United Kingdom. Kilbrandon published his report in <b9_0>1973<b9_0/> recommending the establishment of <a4_2>a <a4_0><a4_1>directly elected Scottish Assembly<a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/> to legislate for the majority of domestic Scottish affairs.
